Line 59: Line 59:
In 2008, Google developed a partnership with [[GeoEye]] to launch a satellite providing Google with high-resolution (0.41 m monochrome, 1.65 m color) imagery for [[Google Earth]]. The satellite was launched from [[Vandenberg Air Force Base]] on September 6, 2008.<ref>{{cite news|url=GeoEye launches high-resolution satellite|title=GeoEye launches high-resolution satellite|last=Shalal-Esa|first=Andrea|date=2008-09-06|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=February 26, 2010|location=Washington}}</ref> Google also announced in 2008 that it was hosting an archive of [[Life Magazine]]'s photographs as part of its latest partnership. Some of the images in the archive were never published in the magazine.<ref>{{cite news |title=Google gives online life to Life mag's photos |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/27802744/ |quote=Google Inc. has opened an online photo gallery that will include millions of images from Life magazine's archives that have never been seen by the public before. |agency=Associated Press |date=2008-11-20 |accessdate=2010-02-25 |location=Mountain View, California}}</ref> The photos were [[watermark]]ed and originally had copyright notices posted on all photos, regardless of [[public domain]] status.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://searchengineland.com/google-to-host-10-million-time-life-unpublished-images-15513 |title=Google Hosting Time-Life Photo Archive, 10 Million Unpublished Images Now Live |publisher=[[Search Engine Land]] |author=Greg Stirling |date=November 18, 2008 |accessdate=2009-12-20 }}</ref>
In 2008, Google developed a partnership with [[GeoEye]] to launch a satellite providing Google with high-resolution (0.41 m monochrome, 1.65 m color) imagery for [[Google Earth]]. The satellite was launched from [[Vandenberg Air Force Base]] on September 6, 2008.<ref>{{cite news|url=GeoEye launches high-resolution satellite|title=GeoEye launches high-resolution satellite|last=Shalal-Esa|first=Andrea|date=2008-09-06|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=February 26, 2010|location=Washington}}</ref> Google also announced in 2008 that it was hosting an archive of [[Life Magazine]]'s photographs as part of its latest partnership. Some of the images in the archive were never published in the magazine.<ref>{{cite news |title=Google gives online life to Life mag's photos |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/27802744/ |quote=Google Inc. has opened an online photo gallery that will include millions of images from Life magazine's archives that have never been seen by the public before. |agency=Associated Press |date=2008-11-20 |accessdate=2010-02-25 |location=Mountain View, California}}</ref> The photos were [[watermark]]ed and originally had copyright notices posted on all photos, regardless of [[public domain]] status.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://searchengineland.com/google-to-host-10-million-time-life-unpublished-images-15513 |title=Google Hosting Time-Life Photo Archive, 10 Million Unpublished Images Now Live |publisher=[[Search Engine Land]] |author=Greg Stirling |date=November 18, 2008 |accessdate=2009-12-20 }}</ref>
â
In 2010, Google made its first investment in a renewable-energy project, putting up $38.8 million into two wind farms in North Dakota. The company announced the two locations will generate 169.5 megawatts of power, or enough to supply 55,000 homes. The farms, which were developed by NextEra Energy Resources, will reduce fossil fuel use in the region and return profits. NextEra Energy Resources sold Google a twenty percent stake in the project in order to get funding for project development.<ref>"Google Invests in Two Wind Farms." Wall Street Journal. 4 May 2010. Web. 4 May 2010. <http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748704342604575222420304732394.html?mod=WSJ_business_LeadStoryCollection>.</ref> Also in 2010, Google purchased Global IP Solutions, a Norway based company that provides web-based teleconferencing and other related services. This acquisition will enable Google to add telephone-style services to its list of products.<ref>Google's Latest Telephony Play<http://www.forbes.com/2010/05/18/google-microsoft-videoconferencing-technology-telephony.html?boxes=techchannellighttop></ref> On May 27, 2010, Google announced it had also closed the acquisition of the mobile ad network, AdMob. This purchase occurred days after the [[Federal Trade Commission]] closed its investigation into the purchase.<ref>By Chloe Albanesius, PC Magazine. "[http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2364268,00.asp It's Official: Google-AdMob Deal Approved]." May 27, 2010.</ref>Google acquired the company for an undisclosed amount.<ref>BY Chole Albanesius, PC Magazine. "[http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2355609,00.asp Google Acquires Mobile Display Ad Firm AdMob]." November 9, 2010.</ref>
+
In 2010, Google made its first investment in a renewable-energy project, putting up $38.8 million into two wind farms in North Dakota. The company announced the two locations will generate 169.5 megawatts of power, or enough to supply 55,000 homes. The farms, which were developed by NextEra Energy Resources, will reduce fossil fuel use in the region and return profits. NextEra Energy Resources sold Google a twenty percent stake in the project in order to get funding for project development.<ref>{{cite news |title=Google Invests in Two Wind Farms |first1=Scott |last1=Morrison |first2=Cassandra |last2=Sweet |newspaper=Wall Street Journal |date=2010-05-04 |url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748704342604575222420304732394.html}}</ref> Also in 2010, Google purchased Global IP Solutions, a Norway based company that provides web-based teleconferencing and other related services. This acquisition will enable Google to add telephone-style services to its list of products.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Gomes |first1=Lee |date=2010-05-18 |title=Google's Latest Telephony Play |work=Forbes.com |publisher=Forbes, Inc. |url=http://www.forbes.com/2010/05/18/google-microsoft-videoconferencing-technology-telephony.html}}</ref> On May 27, 2010, Google announced it had also closed the acquisition of the mobile ad network, AdMob. This purchase occurred days after the [[Federal Trade Commission]] closed its investigation into the purchase.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.appscout.com/2010/05/google_closes_acquisition_of_a.php |title=Google Closes Acquisition of AdMob |last1=Albanesius |first1=Chloe |date=2010-05-27 |work=AppScout |publisher=Ziff Davis Publishing Holdings Inc. |accessdate=2010-06-16}}</ref>Google acquired the company for an undisclosed amount.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2355609,00.asp |title=Google Acquires Mobile Display Ad Firm AdMob |last1=Albanesius |first1=Chloe |date=2010-11-09 |work=PC Magazine |publisher=Ziff Davis Publishing Holdings Inc. |accessdate=2010-06-16}}</ref>
